Author: mhb
Content:
No, but a priori I would assume Philip Morris is a good company. Knowing what their product is, I revise that opinion.

It looks like there is a larger back story to this than was originally obvious to me from your essay and that has loomed very large in your estimation of Digikey's character. Framing it as a David and Goliath morality play is good marketing but I think a more nuanced view is reasonable - they're somewhat less good than I originally believed.

I prefer the former

Don't we all...The latter is a solved problem with a million variants, the former is new ground.

Would you recommend any papers/books in that area?

Author: mattjung
Content:
You are right. I used the term "enterprise software" only as a contrast to "consumer software". The "Fortune 5,000,000" is probably the best target market for a startup.

Why? Targeting large enterprises (what the company I work for does) is also an extremely difficult market, but for other reasons than the consumer market. Selling to large enterprises requires professionel and experienced sales people with very good industrie contacts. You also might run into the "small company problem", i.e. you don't sell because you look too small and you don't have enough customer references. Not much fun!

Author: aswanson
Content: Nice work.  From the looks of it, I thought it was some new thing that Adobe or some huge company put out.  When I read that you guys were from YC, I was shocked (not that YC doesn't put out good stuff) that you built such a good product with so little funding.  Keep at it!

Author: spif
Title: Ask PG: Can we have a feature to save links in Hacker News?
Content:
It is often near impossible to find useful links back after a few days.

Reddit has a feature where you can save a link. It would be very helpful to have this same functionality in HN. I know there's heaps of services like Del.icio.us and Ma.gnol.ia, but in the vain of keeping things simple.

Author: ssharp
Content:
>>> If you're concerned about learning, you will learn more about business in one good hands on project than 2 years of formal education.

That statement pretty much discredits everything you say. Have you run through an entire MBA program? This statement is unbelievably ignorant.

As for CMU, they certainly do have an "MBA" program. Also, CMU is a 2nd tier B-School. It's still very good but not at the top of U.S. MBA programs.
